abstract.p: Drawings of the apteryx in three positions.

div.p: Here is the apteryx in three positions, resting on his beak, wading in a great pool, and running forth in quest of cockroaches or bugs or anything else he can catch. I send it for your amusement

div.note: The date is taken from the sale catalogue. According to the catalogue, the letter is written on paper with the letterhead of the Zoological Society of London.

Rowland Hill collected both living and dead specimens of animals and birds. He lived in Shropshire, and was acquainted with CD’s friend Thomas Campbell Eyton (Correspondence vol. 1, letter from T. C. Eyton, 12 November 1833). Apteryx is the kiwi bird; CD had referred to Apteryx in Journal of researches 2d ed., p. 200. Three small sketches appear at the head of the letter; however, it is not possible to reproduce them.

The letter advertised in the sale catalogue is incomplete; only the first leaf was for sale. [N.B.It appears that this letter, which should be dated 6 January 1852 because the first kiwi only arrived in London in December 1851, was written by William John Broderip. According to the archivist at the Zoological Gardens, Broderip visited that day; and according to the person who provided this information, the handwriting matches Broderip's. March 2022.]
